concept.title: Impact of documentation debt
concept.shortdesc: Eliminating documentation debt has been a concern for development teams of all sizes since the early days of coding.

section.p: Strategies to manage documentation debt and bring it in sync with the code involve either having a full time team of technical authors or committing large amounts of resources usually late in the development cycle. The problem with this is that as soon as you write another line of code the documentation debt starts to grow again and the code immediately becomes legacy code.

Business also shares this concern, as documentation debt can affect the bottom line, increasing time to market, higher support costs, lower uptake of product, poorer reputation and overall higher documentation costs. Development departments have reduced performance due to higher costs for document maintenance, refactoring and development and more inefficiencies with longer on-boarding times for new developers, inability to reuse code and increased technical debt.

Furthermore, intellectual property that isn’t properly specified and accurately documented has a lower perceived value to potential investors. This is because it is more difficult to assess your code’s reliability and is riskier investing in developing it further without complete and accurate documentation making it more difficult to predict or defend your software’s value.
